Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 291d709d3505cb345259e7d78eb6c8b765499c1b
now that this sits on master, would be good to add the commit hash here
Done

I read the code. IMO this doesn't save any DBus traffic, does it?

It saves time transferring payload, and time marshalling/unmarshalling the response.

> I read the code. IMO this doesn't save any DBus traffic, does it?
> 
> It saves time transferring payload, and time marshalling/unmarshalling the response.

Correct.  We could have future implementations that do a more optimized version that DOES save dbus traffic for specific use cases, but I do think this needs to come first.
Ack
Could add something on the protocol validator ?
Added protocol validator to results.
Be careful with the extra white space changes :)
Fixed.  This was a merge conflict on another refactor.

This doesn't get all the good return code though.. I would think we would want a check for 200 - 299 like 
inverse of this https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/77665bdac1063ae547890a983daeab7f4320457d/http/http_client.hpp#L87

I don't think so, and even if we did, I'd like to see us add incrementally as we find use cases.  For the specific 2xx returns that we have

201 created can't be cached, because it requires an action, and only returned on a POST.
202 accepted is the same thing;  Only done on POST/PATCH.
204, no content has no advantages here.  No-content means that the body was already empty.
206 partial content (we don't use this, but in theory we could) is probably not something we want a user caching at all, if they're requesting a range.

301/307, can't/shouldn't cache a forward.


I think that covers all the cases.
Ack
Seems reasonable to me.
nit: can combine the two branches to save an indent?

We generally don't combine statements like this, and I don't think there's anything in the coding standard that would say that we should combine these?  Generally the advice is the opposite.  There's no lines within the branch that wrap lines, so it's not clear that saving the intent here improves the readability.  Is there something you were thinking about in the style guide in regards to this?

So, there are quite a few places that said "avoid nested branches" or "avoid deep indent"

If you need references,

https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Computer_Programming/Coding_Style/Minimize_nesting
https://www.codeproject.com/Articles/626403/How-and-Why-to-Avoid-Excessive-Nesting

We have two options, one is to combine these two branches. I see a lot of codes combine std::option check and value check.

The other is to invert the if so we return early.

Does that answer your question?
ACK; changes made.  After looking at it, yes, this does make the code a little cleaner.  Done.
should we set this to private? You already have a public interface to modify it.
Done.
Ack
You are already doing this here
Ack
Like not the latest patch set was tested but like 16 was? Is that what you mean by on previous rebase?
Yep.  There were no merge conflicts, so it's unlikely anything broke in the meantime, but I figured it was worth mentioning.
